child.geography: Russian Federation: Karachay-Cherkessia Province. Also in Germany, Turkey.

child.pub-comments: Population: 37,800 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 47,880. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script in Turkey. Language Use: More vigorous in the Russian Federation than Turkey. L1 for about 95%. Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.geography: Georgia: Abkhaz Republic, Black Sea coast. Also in Russian Federation, Turkey, Ukraine.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 101,000 in Georgia (1993). Population total all countries: 112,740. Writing: Cyrillic script, used since 1860s. Georgian (Mkhedruli) script, no longer in use. Language Use: 94% speak it as L1. Statutory provincial language in Abkhazia, co-official with Georgian (1995, Constitution, Article 8).

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Turkey: Istanbul area, near the Sea of Marmara, Haci Osman village.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Language Use: A century ago, there were 50,000 speakers in the Caucasus valleys east of the Black Sea. Shifted to a distinct dialect of Adyghe [ady].

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Kabardino-Balkaria Republic and Karachay-Cherkessia Province. Also in Germany, Jordan, Syria, Turkey, United States.
child.alt-names: Beslenei, East Circassian, Kabard, Kabardino-Cherkes, Kabardo-Cherkess, Upper Circassian

child.pub-comments: Similar to Adygey [ady]. Population: 516,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). 36,700 monolinguals (2002 census). Population total all countries: 1,628,500. Ethnic population: 520,000. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1993–2007.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Adygeya Republic. Also in Egypt, France, Germany, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Macedonia, Netherlands, Syria, Turkey, United States.
child.alt-names: Adygei, Adygey, Circassian, Kiakh, Kjax, Lower Circassian, West Circassian

child.pub-comments: Population: 117,500 in Russian Federation (2010 census). No monolinguals (Ministry of Education, Adygea Republic). Population total all countries: 491,800. Ethnic population: 128,500. Writing: Arabic script, no longer in use. Cyrillic script. Latin script, used in Turkey. Language Use: 96% speak it as L1. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 99% (Ministry of Education, Adygea Republic). Literacy rate in L2: 100% (Ministry of Education, Adygea Republic). Taught in primary schools. Newspapers. New media. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Statutory provincial language in Adyghea (1995, Constitution, Adyghea Republic, Article 2).

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 146,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 153,170. Ethnic population: 118,000 in the Russian Federation. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Taught in secondary schools as special subject. Poetry. Magazines. Newspapers. Radio programs. Films. Bible portions: 1996–2007.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southwest Dagestan Republic, Tsumadinsky district, Khushtada, Tlondoda, Kvanada, and Gimerso; Akhvakhsky district, Tlissi and Tlibisho; a few other communities.
child.alt-names: Bagulal, Bagvalin, Bagwalal, Barbalin, Kvanada, Kvanadin

child.pub-comments: Population: 1,450 (2010 census). Language Use: Home. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus] or Tindi [tin]. Avar [ava] used as literary language. Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southwest Dagestan Republic, Tsumadinsky district. 8 villages; Chechnya Republic.

child.pub-comments: Population: 500 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 5,000 (1990 A. Kibrik). Language Use: Avar [ava] and Russian [rus] used in school and as LWC (2007). Home. Very positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava] or Russian [rus]. Avar is literary language.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Western Dagestan Republic, Tsumadinsky district, Tindi, Angida, Aknada, Echeda, and Tissi villages.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Bagvalal [kva] closely related, but probably not inherently intelligible. Population: 2,150 (2010 census). Language Use: Home, community. Few child speakers (2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Avar [ava] is literary language.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southwest Dagestan Republic, Akhvakhsky district, 6 villages; Kakhib county. 3 villages. Also in Azerbaijan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 210 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Language Use: Home. All children speak Akhvakh. Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava] as the literary language and language of communication between different Akhvakh dialects. Language Development: Russian [rus] is a language of education. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Western Dagestan Republic, Botlikh and Miarsu villages.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 210 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 5,000 (A. Kibrik). Language Use: Few domains. Used by many children (2007). Positive attitudes. Avar [ava] is literary language. Avar and Russian [rus] used in school and for wider communication (Salminen 2007). Language Development: Dictionary.

child.geography: Russian Federation: West Dagestan Republic, Akhvakhsky district. 9 villages.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Karatin and Tokitin dialects are quite different.

Population: 260 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 5,000 (1990 A. Kibrik) or 6,400 (Koryakov 2006). Language Use: Home. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Avar [ava] is literary language. Language Development: Dictionary.

child.pub-comments: Population: 5,800 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 23,800 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: All children learn Andi. Positive attitudes. Russian [rus] used for most key domains. Avar [ava] used as literary language. Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2007.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southwestern Dagestan Republic, Botlikhsky district, Godoberi, Zibirkhali and Beledi.

child.pub-comments: Population: 130 (2010 census). Language Use: Few child speakers (2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava] or Russian [rus]. Avar is literary language. Language Development: Russian used in education. Dictionary.

child.pub-comments: Population: 6,100 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 6,800. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: All ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Russian [rus]. Avar [ava] is literary language. Language Development: Russian used for education. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1999–2007.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southern Dagestan Republic, Tsuntinsky district, Nakhada, Gunzib and Garbutl; Kizilyurtovksy district, Stalskoe. Also in Georgia.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 1,010 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 1,420. Ethnic population: 2,000. Language Use: Avar [ava] and Russian [rus] are used in school and for wider communication (2007). Home. Few child speakers. Mildly positive attitudes. Some also use Russian [rus], Bezhta [kap] or Avar [ava]. Avar is literary language. Language Development: No literacy in Hunzib. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southern Dagestan Republic, Tsuntinsky district, several villages. Also in Georgia.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: May be a separate language.

Population: 12,500 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Ethnic population: 15,400 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Highland users have good language maintenance, those moving to the lowlands show attrition. Few domains. More than half the children speak Dido. Positive attitudes. Avar [ava] is literary language. Language Development: Taught in primary schools.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southwest Dagestan Republic, Tsumadinsky district, Khvarshi, Inkhokvari, Santlada, Kvantlada, and Khonokh villages.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 1,740 (2010 census). 1,000 Inxokvari speakers (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 1,870 (2002 census). Language Use: 50-60% of children speak Khvarshi. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Avar [ava] is literary language. Language Development: Dictionary.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southwestern Dagestan Republic, Tsuntinsky district, Ginukh.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Close to Tsez (Dido) [ddo], but probably not inherently intelligible. Population: 5 (2010 census). Language Use: Family. Few child speakers. Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava], Russian [rus] or Dido [ddo]. Avar is literary language.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Azerbaijan: Quba county, Khinalug village.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 1,000 (Salminen 2007). Language Use: All domains. Some child speakers. Positive attitudes. Azerbaijani is literary language. De facto language of provincial identity in Quba District.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Chechnya Republic, north Caucasus. 63% in rural areas. Also in Georgia, Germany, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Syria, Turkey, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Melkhi transitional dialect to Ingush.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 1,350,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). 233,000 monolinguals. Population total all countries: 1,361,000. Ethnic population: 1,360,000. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Largest Nakh-Daghestanian language. Used in publishing. Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Newspapers. New media. Radio programs. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2012. Statutory provincial language in Chechen Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.geography: Russian Federation: North Caucasus, Ingushetia Republic. Also in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Somewhat intelligible with Chechen [che], more so with contact. Population: 306,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 322,900. Writing: Arabic script. Cyrillic script. Latin script. Language Use: Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Radio programs. Grammar. Bible portions: 2005. Statutory language of provincial identity in Ingushetia (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Georgia: Kakheti Region, Talavei district, Zemo-Alvani (Upper Alvani).
child.alt-names: Bac, Batsaw, Batsba, Batsbi, Batsbiitsy, Batsi, Tsova-Tush, Tush
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 3,420 (2000). Active users may be far fewer than 3,000 (Salminen 2007). Language Use: Modern Bats heavily influenced by Georgian [kat]. Traditional Bats perhaps known by a few elders (Salminen 2007). Few domains. Used by few children. Neutral attitudes. Georgian [kat] used in school and for wider group communication (Salminen 2007). Language Development: Georgian [kat] is literary language. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southeast Dagestan Republic, west of Caspian sea coast; central Caucasus. Also in Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkey, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan.

child.pub-comments: Population: 402,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 788,720. Ethnic population: 412,000 in Russia (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Most domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Newspapers. Radio programs. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1990–2010.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southeast Dagestan Republic, Agulsky and Kurakhsky districts; Moscow; Stavropol region.

child.pub-comments: Population: 29,300 (2010 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language use: 98% speak it as L1. Home. All ages. Positive attitudes. Language Development: Can be taught as a subject in local schools (Salminen 2007). Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2005–2007.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southern Dagestan Republic. Also in Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 126,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 126,900. Ethnic population: 132,000 in Russia (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Development: Magazines. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Azerbaijan: Quba county, Budukh village; in expatriate communities of Deli-Kaya, Pirusti.

child.pub-comments: Population: 1,000 (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 1,000 (1990 A. Kibrik). Language use: All domains. Used by 30%–50% of children. Positive attitudes. Azerbaijani [azj] is literary language.

child.geography: Azerbaijan: Quba county, Kryz, Jek, Khaput, Yergyuj, Alyk villages.
child.alt-names: Dzek, Dzhek, Dzheki, Katsy, Kryc, Kryz, Kryzy

Population: 5,000 (Salminen 2007). Language Use: All domains. Used by 30%–50% of children, but number of child speakers decreasing (2007). Positive attitudes. Azerbaijani is literary language.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Azerbaijan: Northwest, Zakatal and Kakh counties, 16 villages. Also in Russian Federation, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 13,000 in Azerbaijan (1989 census). Population total all countries: 23,673. Ethnic population: 13,300 in Azerbaijan (1989 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script in Azerbaijan. Language Use: Most families still transmit it to children. Language Development: Studied as a subject in local schools (Salminen 2007). Newspapers. Grammar. Bible portions: 2003–2007. De facto language of provincial identity in Tovuz District.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southern Dagestan Republic. Also in Azerbaijan.
child.alt-names: Chal, Mukhad, Myhynnynydy-ch’el, Rutal, Rutultsy, Rutuly

child.pub-comments: Dialects not sharply defined

Population: 30,400 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 47,400. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: 99% as L1. Home. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus] or Tsakhur [tkr]. Lezgin used as literary language [lez]. Language Development: Not a literary language. Taught in primary schools. Grammar. Bible portions: 2004.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Azerbaijan: Oghuz town, Qabala, Niç (about 4,000 speakers), and Mirzabeyli villages. Also in Georgia, Russian Federation, Turkmenistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Oktomberi dialect more divergent from Nic Udi than from Oghuz Udi.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 3,800 in Azerbaijan (2009 census). Population total all countries: 6,590. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language use: Home, community. Used by 30%–50% of children. Neutral attitudes. Udi not seen as prestigious as Russian [rus]. Also use Russian [rus] and sometimes Azerbaijani literary languages; in some areas they also use Armenian [hye] or Georgian [kat]. In Nic children attend Russian language schools. Language Development: Discussing how their language can be saved. Taught in primary schools, through 4th grade. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1902.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Southern Dagestan Republic, Arsha community upper Risor river. 8 villages.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 970 (2010 census). Language Use: Home. Used by many children (2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava] or Russian [rus]. Avar used as the literary language. Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: Population: 486,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 492,490. Ethnic population: 510,000. Writing: Cyrillic Script.
